item.title: Linked: Swag as Economic Barometer
item.description:
Visit Link

The Hustle has a pretty interesting article about the economic power and impact of corporate swag and how well it reflects the state of the economy in general. Also, some sobering stats (under the assumption that they are correct) like it being a $26.1-billion industry or how in 2022 ad spending fell by 6% but promotional swag spending was up 12% or when the industry grew three times quicker than the ad sector and 4 times quicker than the U.S. economy as a whole in 2010. Yikes.

item.title: Noted: New Logos for Paris Basketball by Studio Tyrsa
item.description:
“The Light at the End of the Tower”

(Est. 2018) “Paris Basketball is a French professional basketball club based in Paris. The club currently plays in the LNB Pro A, the first division of basketball in France, and the EuroLeague since 2024–25. Paris plays its home games at the Adidas Arena. Three years after its establishment, Paris promoted to the first-level LNB Pro A for the first time, in 2021. In 2024, the team won the LNB Pro A Leaders Cup and the 2023–24 EuroCup titles.” (Wikipedia)

Design by
Identity: Studio Tyrsa (Paris, France)
Strategy: Yard

Related links
Paris Basketball press release

Relevant quote
We teamed up with Yard who came up with a brief and a strategic approach that consisted in highlighting Paris and its basketball culture, as well as the idea of light. The light for the obvious City of Light, but also the one that puts the spotlight on new talents or the one that dazzles our opponents.

We didn’t want use to use the Eiffel Tower at first, but after exploring many other options, we quickly realized that the most beautiful source of light in Paris was at the top of the Tower. The mix of the shape of the ball, the tower and the light on top then became an evidence to us. Using the club’s actual colors allowed us to play with them and create a lighting effect. The light became the center of the entire identity, and is present in both our PARIS wordmarks as a dot on the letter I, or as a shooting star that creates the loop of the P in our monogram.

In addition to all these elements we’ve also designed a bespoke typeface, inspired by classic basketball fonts but also old Parisian Specimen we found, available in Regular and Italic. It will allow the club to express itself with a unique tone in a way that is consistent with its identity, whether on the back the jerseys, on the screen of the Arena or any communication assets.

Images (opinion after)

Opinion
The old logo was quite generic with a basic basketball — in a combination of sharp and curved lines that were somewhat poorly drawn — and ill-fitting typography. The name and colors could be changed to any other city and it wouldn't have made a difference. The new logo embraces Paris' number one visual cliché — the Eiffel Tower — and cleverly blends it into the grooves of the basketball through a relatively abstract rendition of the landmark. The addition of the light spark at the top helps draw some attention away from the Eiffel Tower in a positive way so that the logo is not just about the Eiffel Tower and I really like the bright-spark feeling it achieves through the combination of blue, red, and white. The execution of the icon is quite nice too and was probably harder to achieve than it would seem at first glance, mixing the mono-width stroke of the grooves with the thicks and thins of the spark. In heavy contrast with the old typography, the new one goes wide… very wide, wrapping almost the full circumference of the logo and it's mostly good but maybe it ends up being too big. The collegiate-looking custom typeface and matching secondary wordmarks are pretty nice as they also have a bit of an urban/industrial feel so it veers away from an American University athletics vibe. The script wordmark is also great but perhaps a little hard to appreciate with so many strokes around it. The monogram starts to feel like a stretch of the concept and the visual language but, like everything else, it is really well done. When seeing all of the assets together the one thing that stands out is that all of the spark elements are different — different angles, different proportions, different skews — and it would have been nice (albeit admittedly difficult) if that was the one element that was more heavily consistent across the myriad styles. Overall, as seen in the uniforms and launch event, everything comes together almost literally in a brilliant way in terms of how luminous the various assets stand out against black backdrops and there is a fun, sport-y energy to all of it.

item.title: Reviewed: Friday Likes 510: From Untitled Macao, Micael Micmas, and Purple
item.description:
“From Untitled Macao, Micael Micmas, and Purple”

Some eccentricity and quirkiness this week, with work from Macau, João Pessoa, and Stockholm.

Dino Kiddo by Untitled Macao

Dino Kiddo is a new spin-off-slash-concept from Dino Burger in Macau, focusing on hot dogs. (As some of you might remember, I Liked Dino Burger back in a Friday of 2021 — I’m actually shook this was three years ago as I could have sworn it was so much more recent.) The identity, designed (then and now) by Untitled Macao, builds on the quirkiness and eccentricity of the original with a menagerie of crudely-drawn animals — some real, some imagined, some just plan unidentifiable — that are delightful in their weirdness. A funky “Kiddo” logo has been added to the already-weird Dino logo and while the logo shouldn’t work with its contradicting letterform shapes — some are squiggly, some are not and some are filled in, some are not — and silly googly eyes on top, it’s perfectly suited for the task. The supporting typography is typeset on weird paths or surrounded by super thick strokes and paired with odd colors but it all just clicks together in its loose approach and basks in its silliness. See full project

Home Burger by Micael Micmas

Home Burger is a burger joint in João Pessoa, a port city in northeastern Brazil, driven by its North Star of “Burger, Fries & Friends”. The identity, designed by local designer Micael Micmas, is not the most impressive (or cohesive) but, bruh, that “HB” monogram is a thing of beauty and worth celebrating. It would be impressive alone that it managed to blend an “H” and “B” together but to then reveal a hamburger in the negative space? Brilliant. The sign at night is so satisfying too with the dark sky “coloring” the burger in the negative space. As mentioned, the accompanying identity is not amazing but it’s not bad either… perhaps one too many typefaces without a clear purpose. Nothing a churro couldn’t make me overlook though. See full project

Lykke by Purple

Lykke is a coffee roaster in Farsta, Sweden, that not just sources its beans from but partners with and invests in farmers around the world. The identity, designed by Stockholm, Sweden-based Purple, takes matters into their own hands with a charmingly hand-made approach, first in the form of the wobbly rainbow logo and second in the abundance of spray-painted elements that manifest in different ways in the packaging and that also yield a small library of spot illustrations to use across other applications. More than a design system, a playful sensibility extends across the packaging of the multitude of coffee and tea offerings through bright colors, bold typography, and thick hand-drawn elements. If I had to choose one sample to order for keeps it would be Ugly Cute. See full project

item.title: Linked: Lost in Space
item.description:
Visit Link

Davide Mascioli, a Designer and Art Director in Rome, Italy, has put together the Space Exploration Logo Archive, a digital archive of over 370 logos related to space exploration from the 1940s to the present day, all available for perusing (and downloading in vector form) at the link. If you prefer your space exploration logos in book form, Davide has also launched a Kickstarter to produce a Risograph-printed publication divided into 5 mini-books, each distinguished by a unique color palette. Yes, please.

item.title: Noted: New Logo and Livery for Aeromexico by W+K Mexico
item.description:
“The Eagle has Fallen”

(Est. 1934) “Aeromexico, Mexico’s global airline, operates more than 600 daily flights and has its main hub in Terminal 2 of the Mexico City International Airport. Its destinations network features 89 cities on three continents; including 43 destinations in Mexico, 18 in the United States, 17 in Latin America, 4 in Europe, 3 in Canada, and 3 in Asia. The Group’s operating fleet of 133 aircraft is comprised of Boeing 787 and 737 jet airliners and next generation Embraer 170 and 190 models. In 2012, the airline announced its most significant investment strategy in Mexican aviation history, purchasing 100 Boeing aircraft including 90 MAX B737 jet airliners and 10 B787-9 Dreamliners. As a founding member of the SkyTeam airline alliance, Aeromexico offers customers more than 1,000 destinations in 177 countries served by the 20 SkyTeam airline partners rewarding passengers with benefits.”

Design by
W+K Mexico (Mexico City, Mexico)

Related links
2024 Brand New Reviewed post
Adlatina story

Relevant quote
According to Jessica Apellániz, chief creative officer of W+K Mexico, the new visual identity and all communication are the result of the company's own renewal and modernization process, with its new purpose as its central axis. "The purpose, elevating the trip to an extraordinary experience, is the narrative line of our main message. We present the feeling of pride that only those who were born here can identify. The recognition that, as Mexicans, as a country and as an airline, we believe in the extraordinary. The communication is a recognition of the size and growth of this brand and its desire to continue elevating and exporting our culture. This is the narrative that inspired the renewal of the brand's image and voice," she said.

"The image change reflects our own evolution, a symbol of the rejuvenation of our relationship with all our stakeholders and, above all, with Mexican society. Today, Mexico is bigger, more interesting, varied and richer than ever. That's why we incorporated new textures, colors and materials to our image and spaces, giving us new ways to express ourselves, preserving our traditions and history, ancient and contemporary," he added.

For his part, Pablo de Arteaga, president of the agency, concluded: "This project is the result of a close collaboration between Aeroméxico and Wieden+Kennedy México. Since 2023, we have worked hand in hand to bring to life the main communication projects of one of the most emblematic brands in the country. Aeroméxico has allowed us to use all our capabilities as an agency, from our design area, with the development of its new logo and all its applications, to the creation of campaigns that connect deeply with Mexican culture."

Images (opinion after)

Opinion
Earlier this year, we had a Reviewed post on Mucho's identity overhaul for Aeromexico and in it I wrote, “It probably wasn’t even on the table but not changing the Eagle Warrior icon was the best decision possible. It’s one of the best airline icons and is so broadly recognized.” Given the timing of Mucho's project release and the relaunch to coincide with Aeromexico's 90th anniversary, it pains me to say that changing the logo WAS on the table and that, for some reason, they didn't give Mucho a shot at it (or maybe the did) and instead opted to give the assignment to an advertising agency that — #sorrynotsorry for the blanket statement — are notoriously bad at doing logo and identity work and this is a prime example. The “Eagle Warrior” icon probably hit its apex of epic-ness in 1981 and if I had been writing Brand New in 1988 I would have probably been as upset with the change then as I am now given the shift in design approach and changing the extremely satisfying geometry of the 1981 version (which was the result of it being drawn by hand). The 1998 version was slowly pulling away from the harder geometry of its predecessor with some curvature added to the head-dress and face but it stayed true to its essence and had really become one of the best and most recognizable icons in the country. Call me patriotic or nostalgic or close-minded or short-sighted but I abhor the new icon (and wordmark, which I will get to) and I don't think I've used that word in a long time. Perhaps there were some market forces and industry-insider knowledge that demanded a logo change but I personally don't see why there was any need whatsoever as Aeromexico has a good brand reputation and there is no evident design gain from the change. Not in how it reproduces or performs nor in how it represents the airline. The execution of the new icon is not “wrong”… it's arguably well executed but the shift to the wispy gestures, more detailed face, and less abstract approach is literally uncalled for — it does not improve the icon in any way and it even manages to feel cheaper and less sophisticated. My disdain for the new icon is enhanced by the atrocious wordmark that has curves in the absolute wrong places and one little wing each on the “A” and “M” to make up for the lack of caps. They look ridiculous. That “I”? Just, no. And that “C”? Someone call it an Uber because it showed up at the wrong party. The wordmark is embarrassingly bad. The only remotely positive thing I can say about the change from the old logo is the removal of the wavy red line because it had no business being there. The livery is bad by proxy but, to its credit, the old one wasn't that great either. One thing worth pointing out is the use of the stripe-y motif established by Mucho, which also plays out in the Times Square ad and in a few other loose images I found while Googling. Lastly, there is a new brand video-slash-manifesto clocking in at 2-plus minutes and for anyone that doesn't understand Spanish and you think you might be missing something in translation as you wade through the confusing visual narrative let me assure you, as a Mexican, it's a mess and none of it makes sense. I really don't even know how to sum it up for you. It attempts to be philosophical, patriotic, empowering, epic, and then some, all delivered in what sounds like the longest concrete poetry reading ever leaving a single, lasting thought: WTF? Overall, and as no surprise if you've read my rant, this is a terrible, unnecessary redesign that has no evident positive impact on Aeromexico.

item.title: Reviewed: New Logo and Packaging for Munchies by Vocabulary
item.description:
“A Case Of”

Launched in 2024, Munchies is a new range of snacks in Canada that include potato chips, tortilla chips, and popcorn. For some, this might be a strong crunch of nostalgia as the Munchies are actually quite old, having first appeared in 1981 as the mascots for Hostess Potato Chips, a popular brand of chips in the 1970s, ’80s, and ’90s, spurred by a partnership between Hostess and Frito-Lay, before they were discontinued in 1996 and rebranded as Lay’s. Munchies has been brought back (or more like introduced anew) as its own brand by PepsiCo Foods Canada and its subsidiary Frito Lay Canada with six, permanent flavors, two of which are a nod to the original Hostess versions — Tangy Ketchup and Old School BBQ potato chips — along with Chili Cheese Stampede tortilla chips, Supreme Sour Cream and Onion tortilla chips, Cheeky Cheddar popcorn and Deliciously All Dressed popcorn. The identity and packaging have been designed by LA-, New York-, and Toronto-based Vocabulary.

Many Canadians will recall Hostess chips, from the 80s and 90s, featuring the Munchies on the bag. The launch of the Munchies chips in 2024 will connect generations, bringing back fond memories of the good old days and feelings of wonder and joy.

“Nostalgia taps into our deepest emotions and memories. When we decided to bring back the Munchies, we knew there was something inherently special about this brand and what it meant to original fans – while introducing the magic to new ones too,” said Jess Spaulding, Chief Marketing Officer, PepsiCo Foods Canada. “We’re excited to see how Canadians welcome the return of the Munchies as they pop up all over the country, in unexpected locations!”

PepsiCo press release

Using, National 2 (Compressed, I believe) as the starting point, the new logo gets this brand off on the right foot, with a good ol’ fashioned drop shadow, a thick stroke, and a vertiginous angle for some instant consumer brand appeal. The main modifications to National are some inverse flares to the stems of the letters that add a fun bounce to the wordmark and it appears the corners have been subtly rounded. This, along with the stroke treatment feels like it could have used a letterer’s touch so that it didn’t feel like a bulk effect from Adobe Illustrator as the resulting letterforms do end up feeling ever so slightly distorted and skewed. Nonetheless, it’s a fun logo. (I’m just now noticing some discrepancies between the logo on the packaging and the logo above, which is taken from the SVG on the website and it seems like a couple of drop shadows are missing on the “M” and “i”*).

* I know I can try and ask for the correct version but I actually prefer to work off of the materials that are put out into the world by the client as that’s what everyone sees.

Originally drawn by Canadian artist Richard Siu, the Munchies are a trio of goblins that were already fun and quirky to begin with and, while some updates have been made, I am glad they were not given a Dora- or Barney-esque update to make them more “contemporary” (heavy on the air quotes). In fact, I would have loved to see an even more authentic redrawing keeping some of that extra fur and stubbier legs or, even more tempting, a de-evolution to a 1960s or 1970s cartoon aesthetic. Still, the new Munchies stay true to the old Munchies and retain their mischievous personality while adopting new behaviors like… turning into a cheese block.

The packaging, unfortunately, is not that great as it looks like a completely different design team was given the logo and illustrations and proceeded to take the brand in a whole other direction with the old-time-y serif, the ribbon device, and the foil-esque border. I think they were trying to be deadpan retro with it but missed the mark as they didn’t take it far enough and they should have probably just adhered to the visual language on their website (and the promo above) where National 2 is more prominent and more in tune with the illustrations. Colors are nice though.

To create an experience unique to the Munchies, in Toronto, consumers are also invited to travel through a simpler time machine and relive the charm of the good old days at The Living Room – an immersive experience that fuses the joy of the simpler times and the wonder of the future in one room- opening later this month.

From September 17th – 21st guests who visit The Living Room at 253 Queen St West, Toronto will have the opportunity to travel back and forward through time as they take a walk down memory lane (through a speakeasy-like doorway) with notable memorabilia, and of course, plenty of Munchies snacks.

PepsiCo press release

With what looks like a very healthy budget, Munchies launched an ambitious pop-up in Toronto with a lot of custom signage and props as well as some fun-looking merch. It’s hard to tell exactly what decade vibe they are going for but my guess is that, as they try to appeal to a Gen Z/ millennial audience, they are just throwing ALL of the decades at them in the hope that one sticks. To their credit, as a Gen X’er, this does hit some nostalgic notes that are not out of pocket.

Overall, this is a fun product with a fun origin story and a fun introduction effort. At a time where niche consumer products and DTC brands are sprouting everywhere with sophisticated and sometimes esoteric designs — see every brand covered on Snaxshot — it’s almost a welcome change to see something more mainstream done with conviction (and budget) to appeal to a broader audience with more simple, wholesome, and tried-and-true design approaches and marketing ploys.
